instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b smoke coming from <RESISTOR>R9990</RESISTOR> when i connect charger
threads.message: Hi. I have board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b and when i open it <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> and <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> was burned out. i replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> but now when i connect charger smoke coming out from <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>. Also i have short on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> pin 4 and pin 7. Anybody can help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b smoke coming from <RESISTOR>R9990</RESISTOR> when i connect charger
threads.message: Look at the diagram. What besides <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> has a path to ground on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>'s pins 4/7? <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>! <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> has one pin on ground, and the other pin on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> pins 4/7. <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> is the only other path to ground here, so replace and fix. <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> acts as a fuse and will blow if something is shorted to ground in front of it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b smoke coming from <RESISTOR>R9990</RESISTOR> when i connect charger
threads.message: i think we will not gona fix it. there is burn hole in board and can be shorted to layer bellow. i removed <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> and i still have short on pin 4,7 on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>.  i think it will go to scrap. but thanks any way for trying to help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b smoke coming from <RESISTOR>R9990</RESISTOR> when i connect charger
threads.message: It is easy enough to isolate all those components and make your own rail with some floating wires and not use the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b smoke coming from <RESISTOR>R9990</RESISTOR> when i connect charger
threads.message: i done it many times. but is burning inside board m8. where hole is

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b smoke coming from <RESISTOR>R9990</RESISTOR> when i connect charger
threads.message: That is why you bypass the board. Only a few components on this rail so easy to construct with some wires. You could also cut out the area of a dead board and wire it into this board. Many possibilities to fix this board, in no way is this board trash.
